title: sendFile() sets wrong video content type
body: For weird reasons `sendFile()` sets the content type to `video/webm` when sending an MP4 video. Happens on IE10 and Firefox latest version.  But not on Chrome's latest.

title: Partial JSON response
body:
Hi, 
Is there a best practice for dealing with large json responses? I have encountered an issue where passing a large array to res.json returns only part of the content to the client. I resolved the issue by having the controller create the json response record by record calling write. Is this the best way to handle it? or is there another way to mitigate it.

title: include given path in _router when app.use(path, router)
body:
Given

```
app = express()
router = express.Router()
// add various things to app & router

app.use '/mount', router
```

then `app` will contain `_router.stack` with the last entry being something like

```
  { handle: 
     { [Function: router]
       params: {},
       _params: [],
       caseSensitive: undefined,
       mergeParams: undefined,
       strict: undefined,
       stack: 
        [ /* whatever */ ] },
    name: 'router',
    params: undefined,
    path: undefined,
    keys: [],
    regexp: /^\/mount\/?(?=\/|$)/i,
    route: undefined } ]
```

Note that the given string (`'/mount'`) is not set in path, or any of the included/underlying objects.
In the case of `app.post('/guess')` this string is available in a path variable.

```
[ { handle: [Function],
            name: '<anonymous>',
            params: undefined,
            path: undefined,
            keys: [],
            regexp: /^\/guess\/?$/i,
            route: 
             { path: '/guess',
               stack: 
                [ /* whatever */ ],
               methods: { get: true } } } ]
```

It would be nice to get the path given in `app.use`. Reason is that I'm walking the routes and middleware to generate some documentation, and the use of nested routes makes it hard to get the proper paths...

title: express 4.9 issue with graceful-fs on node v0.11.13
body:
After updating to the new version, I found a error on the eTag module which is been used for generating eTag headers. Below is the stack trace

```
/var/www/html/grallo/node_modules/express/node_modules/etag/index.js:55
    throw new TypeError('argument entity must be string or Buffer')
          ^
TypeError: argument entity must be string or Buffer
    at etag (/var/www/html/grallo/node_modules/express/node_modules/etag/index.js:55:11)
    at SendStream.setHeader (/var/www/html/grallo/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/index.js:724:15)
    at SendStream.send (/var/www/html/grallo/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/index.js:500:8)
    at onstat (/var/www/html/grallo/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/index.js:585:10)
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:97:15)
```

We are using `express.static` to serve static files

title: Update documentation for res.redirect
body:
I juste spent a fair amount of time finding out why my usage of `res.redirect` did not work, double-checking documentation. I read the code and didn't get any clue on how mountpath-relative redirects were supposed to work, and in fact #2100 & #2086 confirms it's not supposed to work.

Here is the demo pointing out the guilty sentence: https://gist.github.com/naholyr/f6a2903d72d495db6ab7

I think there should be two changes:
- At least remove all this misleading information about mounted apps in this section of documentation
- Maybe add a convenient API to generate absolute mountpath-aware paths, I think `app.path` could be a good candidate

``` js
rootApp.path()                  // → "/"
mountedApp.path()               // → "/mountpath"
// Add support for 
rootApp.path('other/path')      // → "/other/path"
mountedApp.path('other/path')   // → "/mountpath/other/path"
rootApp.path('/other/path')     // → "/other/path"
mountedApp.path('/other/path')  // → "/mountpath/other/path"
```

In my project I carefully add a slash in my mountpath (`app.use('/path/', otherApp)`) and use `res.redirect(app.path() + 'other/path')` but this trailing slash keeps bothering me ;)

title: Remove unnecessary referencing to `this`
body:
Hey :)
I've noticed some places in the code where it isn't really necessary to store `this` in a variable. I've passed current context to `forEach` loops as the second argument just to make things little more readable.

title: pass app as `this` in middleware and route?
body:
I am wondering if it would be better if
express can pass `app` as `this` in the middleware and route?

Currently, I've noticed that `this` is `global` in express, it is a waste and we can only get app via req.app or res.app. I might be picky lol, `this` is shorter than req.app, and it makes sense in a middleware and route.

Just an idea :)

title: tests: fix tests not working with node v0.12
body:
Currently, test/req.ip.js assumes that the connection between the client
and the server is an IPv4 connection. However, depending on the
configuration of the host where this test runs, the connection can be an
IPv4 one or an IPv6 one using an IPv4 mapped address. In the future, it
could also be a "full" IPv6 connection.

This change makes this test handle any type of address.

title: adding methodOverride to examples/route-separation/index.js

title: Using .end() causes Firefox No Element Found error
body:
In the event where you want to just send back an error code the proper way seems to be as follows:

```
res.status(500).end();
```

However this results in an error in Firebug that says "no element found" and gives "Server path name":1 and this links to an empty file referring to the path that it tried on the server. Firefox expects the response to be valid XML with a single root element. If it is not, Firefox issues the "no element found" error.

I was able to avoid this by instead doing:

```
res.set({ 'Content-Type': 'text/plain'});
res.status(500).end();
```

OR

```
res.status(500).send({});
```

What is the preferred way to handle this? Could .end() be changed to set the content type to "text/plain"?

title: 'listening' event for app?
Common API documentation format for all Node packages
body:
I'm the developer behind [Dash](http://kapeli.com/dash), an API documentation browser.

The current state of node packages is that each package has its own custom format for providing documentation (most in a README). This makes things extremely hard if you want to collect all these docs under one app and also an inconvenience for users, as they have to learn how to reference and navigate each doc format of each package they use.

I've asked the NPM team to promote a doc format that node packages should use in hope that the community would embrace it and they've asked me to contact the maintainers of the most popular packages and get them to agree on a format, and if it gets popular with the community it will get supported by NPM as well. The NPM issue is tracked here: https://github.com/npm/newww/issues/100.

Some questions:
1. Have you considered using an API documentation generator for your node package? I've heard of JSDoc over and over, but I've never seen a node package use it for their docs
2. Do you think it would be better if the APIs of node packages would be documented inside the code (where a doc generator would turn them into actual docs), and the READMEs be used just as a guide?
3. Any thoughts about this issue?

title: 3.X documentation should be clearly labeled
body: A Google search lead me to the page at http://expressjs.com/api#res.send, where I thought I was browsing the latest documentation (especially since the top nav highlighted "API reference"). However, this is actually the 3.X documentation. When browsing older documentation, at the very least the "3.X docs" navigation element should be highlighted. It would be nice if there could even be a "band" (like the "Fork me on GitHub" band) that highlights the fact that these are older docs.

title: How to render a 500 response after an uncaught error in express 4?
body:
When there is an error thrown inside an asynchronous function, the error does not go to the error middleware and instead goes to nowhere and the connection gets stuck

e.g.: 

``` js
app.get('/', function(req, res) {
   doSomethingAsync(function(err) {
      throw new Error('some async exception is thrown');
   })
})
```

And then this happens:

```
Possibly unhandled Error: some async exception is thrown
    at ...stacktrace...:95:9
From previous event:
    at ...stacktrace...:82:6)
    at ...stacktrace...:47:6)
    at ...stacktrace...:94:18)
```

When an exception is thrown from within an async process, the response basically hangs until a timeout.

I have tried a bunch of domain middlewares however they all only work for express 3. I am currently on express 4.5 and I am wondering if express had changed that domain no longer works.

Middlewares: https://github.com/brianc/node-domain-middleware

title: Provide hooks into inspecting the response before its sent to the client
body:
As far as i can tell, once code calls res.send() or res.json(), Express takes over processing of the response, and there's no way to post-process the response before it is sent to the client. For example, send() calls ServerResponse.end directly: https://github.com/strongloop/express/blob/master/lib/response.js#L191

It would be nice if there were some way to hook into the response before it was sent to the client. One use case could be adding an Access-Control-Expose-Headers header that included a whitelist of headers on the response. Another use case could be response header logging.

Using express.js 4 with socket.io won't start
body:
I'm using express 4.2.0 and I've done:

``` bash
express node6 --hogan --ejs 
cd node6
npm install
npm install socket.io
```

I went into the [socket.io docs](http://socket.io/docs/) and I copied and pasted the code of the app.js file.

``` javascript
var app = require('express')();
var server = require('http').Server(app);
var io = require('socket.io')(server);

server.listen(80);

app.get('/', function (req, res) {
  res.sendfile(__dirname + '/index.html');
});

io.on('connection', function (socket) {
  socket.emit('news', { hello: 'world' });
  socket.on('my other event', function (data) {
    console.log(data);
  });
});
```

Why is it?

This is the `dpm-debug.log`:

title: Middleware bleeding between routers mounted to the same path
Release 4.9
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.9.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase (they may occur on patches to the previous release).

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add `res.sendStatus` #2297
- [x] Fix behavior of `req.subdomains` for IP hostnames #2308
- [x] Provide client aborted error from `res.sendFile` #2305
- [x] Support `X-Forwarded-Host` in `req.subdomains`

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following command:

``` bash
$ npm install visionmedia/express#4.9
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: app.routes() functionality is missing in 4x
body: In the 3x it was possible to get a list of the route definitions and callbacks using app.routes.  The restructuring in 4x left this functionality out.  Obviously, it can't work the same in 4x as it did in 3x, but an equivalent capability would be useful.  Mostly for testing, but it could also be useful for dealing with dynamic routes.

title: Fix req.subdomains returns when passing IP address as hostname
body:
Currently, when passing an ip address like `127.0.0.1` as hostname, `req.subdomains` returns an array with address parts:  `['0', '127']`. I tried to fix it by returning an empty array instead.

Not sure, however, whether you prefer adding an external dependency (like validator - https://github.com/chriso/validator.js) to check for IP address. (The used regex are taken from it by the way.)

title: 'trust proxies' to exclude private IP addresses
body:
Currently when 'trust proxies' is enabled it looks like req.ip will be set to the first IP in the x-forwarded-for header. That can often be a private/internal network address though. Here's an example from in-flight wifi:

```
x-forwarded-for: "172.19.131.160, 10.38.53.160, 12.130.117.99"
```

req.ip is set to 172.19.131.160, but the actual public IP address is 12.130.117.99. It'd probably make sense to filter out private IPs by default and show the first public IP, or it could be added as an additional setting.

title: Add res.sendStatus method
body: A helpful method for apps that send many simple status code responses, e.g., REST APIs. The body of the response is set using node's http.STATUS_CODES to avoid problems with clients that choke on empty body responses.

title: Disable ETag for `res.sendFile()`
body: `res.sendFile()` accepts an option to disable ETags. It would make sense that `app.disable('etag')` sets `sendFile()`s `options.etag` to `false` for you. This is a breaking change so it would have to wait for `5.x`.

title: Default to production
body:
I think setting the app env to 'production' by default is safer/easier.
1. In case the developer is lazy in setting the NODE_ENV on the server, the app is still is a secure operating mode.
2. It is much easier to set NODE_ENV to development on a local copy of the site than it is to set NODE_ENV to production on a server.

title: ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH for secure connection
body:
Hello.  I am getting this ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH error when I have ssl enabled for my site.  My server is using express v4.8.0.  

The data transfer ends up halting mid-stream (see wget output below).

Steps to debug:
- When I shorten the data length, the transfer will pass.  
- When I switch to an unsecured connection, the entire data set is transferred.  
- If I try changing the data being sent, but still have a large data set, the transfer still fails (ie: not related to content).

Output from wget:
kehle-mac:~ pgkehle$ wget http://192.168.56.120/api/fundfamily/full?api_key=42373869-a8b6-4ed8-ae47-2e480213fd41 --no-check-certificate
--2014-08-06 12:45:47--  http://192.168.56.120/api/fundfamily/full?api_key=42373869-a8b6-4ed8-ae47-2e480213fd41
Connecting to 192.168.56.120:80... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: 89326 (87K) [application/json]
Saving to: 'full?api_key=42373869-a8b6-4ed8-ae47-2e480213fd41.17'

title: '/' route breaks strict routing
new qs module packaged to npm, rev to version 1.0.0
body: New version of qs published to npm.  Includes fixes for security issue from old repo like - https://github.com/visionmedia/node-querystring/pull/114

title: Remove name from "Lead Maintainer"
body:
Hello!

Please can someone remove my name from "Lead Maintainer" under https://github.com/strongloop/express#contributors ? It is causing me some legal weirdness right now.

title: "Route bootstrapping" link is broken
body: At the http://expressjs.com/faq.html page, "Route bootstrapping" link under "How should I structure my application?" section is broken, resulting in a 404 error.

title: Fix app.use('/blog', mw1, mw2, blogApp)
body: This fixes the use case of mounting another app with preceding middleware, as introduced by #2224

title: Alias `res.sendfile` as `res.sendFile`
define session_id as a GUID
body:
Hi

Is there any way to define the session_id as a GUID. I am storing session in ms SQL 2008 and seems to make sense to me to use a GUID for the column data type rather than nvarchar(255).

... please fee free to say if this is a silly idea

thanks

title: Every simple request make memory group up，memory leak?
body:
I've a static ExpressJS Server , create by cmd

```
express myapp  

```

When i start the server it uses 20MB of v8 heap. If i do a page reload every second the heap used grow continuously. After 4 hours it goes to 40MB of v8 heap used. The total v8 heap goes to 80MB and the RSS (total memory used by the process) goes to 130MB.

Why this simple and static server uses so much ram? It seems a memory leak. If i don't stop the page reload, the used memory keeps growing.

It's impossible to do larger projects if a simple static server like this uses too much ram.

NodeJS version: v0.10.28 ExpressJS version: 4.2

EDIT: I noticed that it's a problem with NodeJS, because i tried node-static instead of express, and while the used/total V8 heap stayed constant, the RSS memory used by nodejs continued to grow up.

title: Revert the change that breaks a test case
body: Recreated the PR from my personal fork

title: Revert the example change that breaks a test
body: One of the tests check for hard-coded repo name url. It's now broken due to repo change.

title: Route middleware executed twice
res.send(200) vs res.status(202).end()
body:
Hello,

I'm using `res.send(202)` which gives this warning:
`express deprecated res.send(status): Use res.status(status).end() instead`

The documentation says no such thing:
http://expressjs.com/api.html#res.send

> Finally when a Number is given without any of the previously mentioned bodies, then a response body string is assigned for you. For example 200 will respond will the text "OK", and 404 "Not Found" and so on.

I like this feature because it automagicly puts in the right, human readable, response body.

When I use `res.status(202).end()` the response body is not automatically set.
In the tests it is set manually:
https://github.com/strongloop/express/blob/master/test/res.status.js

So is it really deprecated and are the docs not updated? And if it is deprecated is there anything that has the same functionality (i.e. response body string)

Edit: I found out this was recently deprecated in this commit: https://github.com/strongloop/express/commit/fd3b40533bafa7e136f68354d0be470bfe60a51c
So maybe @dougwilson can help out?

title: Change repository reference
body: Change visionmedia to strongloop

title: Refactored the settings (config) system to reduce confusion with app.set() and app.get() methods, as per issue #2216
Alias `res.sendfile` as `res.sendFile`
body: `sendfile` is the wrong casing, so I always get it wrong.  Can we just alias it as `res.sendFile`?

title: express 4 setup static from required module fails
body:
I raised a question on SO about the topic but have not got much feedback so assuming it is a bug, here is the question for additional context:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24985467/express-4-setup-static-from-required-module-fails

Gist of it is that when I use the static middleware in my app.js it works fine, if I use it with the same absolute directory in another file which is included via a module (passed the app instance) it blows up.

A bit of a blocker for me at the moment, it may not be a bug but I cannot see anything different between the 2 calls.

I am using Windows 8.1 and nodejs 0.11.13

title: This repo needs to belong in the expressjs org.
body:
I seem to have lost contrib rights :(

But more importantly, I think this needs to live in the express org and not under a company.

title: Default responder should not console.error 4xx errors
body: Right now the default handler (last step) will `console.error` when it gets an `err`, otherwise 404. I think that it probably shouldn't `console.error` when the `err` it got was a 4xx error, mainly because a 4xx is supposed to be a client error, of which the server admin probably cannot do anything about. Adding a custom error handler could, of course, let the user log 4xx error all they wanted--this is just about the default behavior. It could probably wait until express 5, though.

title: 4.7.0 depd error:
body:
Seeing this error in express 4.7.0 (from https://github.com/pouchdb/pouchdb/issues/2537).  Downgrading to 4.6.1 solves the problem.

```
[0mGET /test_repl_remote/ [32m200 [0m0.840 ms - 59[0m

/home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express/node_modules/depd/index.js:259
  var file = callSite.getFileName() || '<anonymous>'
                      ^
TypeError: Cannot call method 'getFileName' of undefined
    at callSiteLocation (/home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express/node_modules/depd/index.js:259:23)
    at Function.log (/home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express/node_modules/depd/index.js:201:12)
    at deprecate (/home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express/node_modules/depd/index.js:124:9)
    at ServerResponse.send (/home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express/lib/response.js:97:7)
    at ServerResponse.res.send (/home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express-pouchdb/index.js:131:10)
    at /home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/node_modules/pouchdb-server/node_modules/express-pouchdb/index.js:576:25
    at /home/travis/build/pouchdb/pouchdb/lib/utils.js:396:11
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:415:13)
```

I'm guessing this was introduced in https://github.com/visionmedia/express/commit/fd3b40533bafa7e136f68354d0be470bfe60a51c?

title: Problem to set views dir in 4.x
How do the template engines work?
body: I see that 14 template engines are supported by Express but I cannot seem to find in the code where they are being used. I see how new ones are added but not the "defaults". Could someone please explain to me how the engines in Consolidate.js are being used inside this project?

title: promises

Second middleware stack
Express installing issue.

I am new to NodeJs. I am trying to install express module in my system. However I am getting the below error, could you please help in resolving the error.

Package.json used is:

```
{
  "name": "hello-world",
  "description": "hello world test app",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": true,
  "dependencies": {
    "express": "3.x"
  }
}
```

I have created the above package.json file in the folder "C:\NodePrograms\hello-world" and the ran the below command.

```
C:\NodePrograms\hello-world>npm install
```
